content:
9, 2014
												Games of The Elder Scrolls series have some very clear expectations to them and must adhere to some very specific core concepts, Skyrim does not tarry too far from the mark.This game has many weaknesses that almost universally stem from it's multiplatform development - cities feel like villages and villages don't feel at all, this is entirely because of the limitations of the engine and the consoles.  Weapons and armour are one size fits all and all armours of the same material are identical, there is no wear and tear of your items...  Money from a thousand years ago does not draw comment when given to a vendor.  You have no useful journal system, instead the map tells you exactly where to go for everything.  Many things that disrupt the immersion within the game.Play this game once on a vanilla play through and then add in the mods, the base game is good, and it will help you appreciate the platform you are playing on a thousand times over when you play a second game using mods.You will mod this title, you will mod it to hell and back.  You will love it for the mods that shore up the weaknesses and enable new and wonderful things in the game.  Steam Workshop integration sounds nice, but it's not, the game's mod interface is garbage and the Workshop prevents a lot of the mods you will want.  You will end up using Nexus Mods and their Nexus Mod Manager or the Slipstream Mod Manager to handle all your mods.  There are mods to patch problems, to reenable content, replace bad textures, enhance combat, add items, add NPCs...  Whatever your heart may desire, the mods are there.The game is good, genuinely good, but it could have been so much better.  One hopes that Fallout 4 learns the lessons presented by the mods of Skyrim, rather than dooming modders to recreating their efforts in the next version of the engine.Any gamer worth their salt has already got this game and has played at least some of it.

content:
er 3, 2015
												Disclaimer: Before I purchased this on Steam in October 2015, I had 1,456 hours put into the Xbox 360 version, and 68 hours in the PS3 version, so hopefully that puts my low PC game-time in perspective. Since the review, I have added almost 200 hours to the Remastered version for the PS4.The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is one of my favorite games of all time. I was excited for the release back on 11/11/11, as I am a fan of all of The Elder Scrolls titles. The previews of Skyrim were beautiful, and though the game world was obviously smaller than some of its predecessors (Arena and Daggerfall in particular), the game would still prove to be larger than most modern games of its type. Skyrim was the first game I pre-ordered in over three years at the time of its release. My expectations were sky high, and yet the game surpassed them. I spent 101 hours in the game in its first week. Very few games can pull me in so mercilessly, and I play hundreds of them.This intro brings me to the subject of why Skyrim deserves your time, if you're not already one of the millions of people who own it. Skyrim is an open world action RPG that does not control how you play it, throwing hundreds of possibilities at you in terms of how you level, explore, complete questlines, et cetera. The world is packed full of content and secrets, to where I am close to having lived in this world for 2,000 hours of my life and am still discovering new things from time to time. You can choose a character from a variety of races with their own perks and abilities, and the character creation system is quite impressive. From there, you complete an introductory quest, and are set free to explore the world as you wish. You can choose to rush through the main questline, or you can spend hundreds of hours ignoring it. There are multiple full questlines for you to choose from. You can choose to complete them all with one character, or choose only a few depending on how you are building your character (an assassin build may choose to utilize the Thieves' Guild and Dark Brotherhood questlines and ignore the Companions and Mages' College questlines, for example). In addition, there are hundreds of side quests and objectives that can be picked up from conversations with NPCs, reading books that speak of legends that you can actually go out into the world and explore for yourself, or even walking through the right place at the right time. Completing quests can sometimes yield you new quests, even if not right away (completing some quests will cause the quest giver to write you a letter later, for example, updating you on events and asking you to return, even weeks after you finished the first objective).The world is lush with detail. NPCs will change their opinion of you due to things you've done, and some will even like/hate you depending on your race or who you've decided to align with on quests. Some will also agree to come on your adventures with you--permanently (or until death...which, I suppose, is still permanently). They will fight by your side and utilize anything that you give them, from armor to weapons to potions, so you can have a two person team at all times if you wish. Bards will sing tales of quests you've completed, if applicable, and people will hire thugs or even the Dark Brotherhood to hunt you down if you've somehow wronged them (including stealing from their homes or shops). Small details are in the world, from a burned down house with a corpse that has a fire scroll in its inventory, to two skeletons on a freezing shoreline, with one of the skeletons stuck in a bear trap. Hundreds of books are scattered throughout the world to give you insight into some of the lore of the world. Characters from past Elder Scrolls games are mentioned in conversations or journals/notes from time to time, giving a welcome nod to your adventures of the past if you've played previous games.Skyrim is one of the few games that rises above a "game" for me and almost becomes like a second life. Its level of rich detail and ability to completely immerse can make players hold grudges, make friends, and even work and make an honest living in-game, while going home to your family every once in a while (in a home that you built, if you have the Hearthfire expansion, which I highly recommend). If a companion dies, you can go to her/his hometown and visit the tomb, if you so wish. This is also one of the few games that is so much fun to go through while choosing to play it unconventionally (for example, I've done playthroughs where I've refused to directly kill anyone, using only defensive magics and conjuration spells and having a companion, and playthroughs where I refuse to use fast travel). I've heard that mods are great for the game, though I don't personally care for mods and play the game in its vanilla state.To address criticisms of the game, Skyrim is not and will never be its predecessors. Its world is just that--Skyrim--and will not have the majestical fantasy landscapes of Morrowind. Magic is quite simplified as compared to Oblivion, and the leveling system is not quite as exploitative as the fourth game in the series, either. You can become overpowered in the game, and you can end up having so much money in your coffers that it's ridiculous. I love the other games in the series, but I love each one for its uniqueness. Skyrim happens to be my favorite of them all, quite possibly because of its ability to feel so personal, like you're truly in this world and truly making friends and a difference. So while it is a bit "modernized" compared to the previous games, the world is so vast and there is always so much to do that it never quite feels like a video game; it feels like an entire world to escape to.Skyrim is so vast and wonderful that it is impossible to do it justice in such a review. I could go on listing this game's strengths and end up having a novel on my hands. I recommend this game more than I recommend most, and is one of the few I can legitimately give a 10/10 to, even considering its minor flaws. Do yourself a favor and pick it up if you haven't tried it yet; chances are that you will enjoy it immensely.

There are also lots of interesting optional missions I think u will spend a lot more time doing side tasks instead of the main story  :D  All in all, TES V: Skyrim is the best game of this series. It really worth that price.

ber 25, 2014
												What can you say about Elder Scrolls series ? It's more popular than a picture of Jesus holding a pug with a bowtie, and rightfully so. Most of the series issues are countered by the fact that talented, sometimes downright disturbingly obsessive modding community probably modded them out and Skyrim is no exception. Even if you sink more than hundered hours in vanilla version, you can still find something you haven't done and want to do. Want to spend all your time force-pushing chickens around town ? Sure ! Wanna put buckets over NPCs faces while they're delivering important pieces of exposition ? You got it ! While I'm usually opposed to "make your own fun" kind of games, doing your own thing is bread and butter of Skyrim, and that's what makes it so popular. Yeah, it may be a bit more simplified (for the sake of accessibility) than older TES games and maybe enviroments and combat get a bit boring and repetitive after a while, but it all falls flat when you can summon 5000 wheels of cheese and roll them down the mountain on unsuspecting goats.

number of helpful: 30 of 44 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an Open-world RPG with an awesome story and it has one of the biggest world to explore in any games ever made! In this game, you play as the Dragonborn, the chosen one that is meant to protect Skyrim from dragons.Honestly, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is probably one of the best game on Steam. The ambiance and everything is just so great! It's still one of the best selling games on Steam even 3 years after it's release! If you haven't played it yet and are you not sure if you should buy it, you can check my personal score below.  Category Rating /10 Details   Gameplay 8.1 The game is very well designed. You can set hotkeys for multiple spells or weapons at once, you can do questlines and misc quests at any times as long as you have the requirements, there's tons of content to explore... The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim doesn't offer anything new to the genre, however, and it's not very well balanced. Some dragons are easier to kill than some types of undeads found in dungeons. Also the AI can be quite confusing: sometimes monsters stands still and let you kill them, sometimes enemies do not even notice you walking in front of them with a high stealth level. Everybody can play the game due to good difficulty settings, but keep in mind the controls are poor and there's some weird balance going on!   Graphics 8.0 The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim graphics are nice. Some things like Snow and NPCs are not very appealing, but during the time you play, you will find tons of amazing landscapes, skies, buildings and forests... That's for the base game of course, because you can make the game more beautiful with mods. As for the animations, most are fine, but rolling and ragdoll deaths are not so well done. The interface is simple and has just the right amount of information.   Atmosphere 8.5 The music is totally amazing. It really fits the game: fighting music is intense and while exploring, the music really sets the atmosphere. Sound effects are alright, though repetitive. My opinion on voice acting is a bit more complex though. Honestly, I am impressed by some characters voice acting, like Cicero, Astrid, Senera, Sheogorath... They have very unique and amazing voices. On the other hand, some NPCs shares the same voice; like, litterally not just the same voice actor, but the same actual voice in game on multiple NPCs.   Performance 4.8 Here's the weak point of the game, definately. The amount of bugs is just catastrophic. I could write a paragraph longer than this review to list all the bugs i've experienced while playing The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim for around 140 hours. Game breaking bugs where you cannot complete certain quest and hope that you can complete them with the console. Sometimes you need to restart the entire game from the start if you absolutely need to complete a certain quest. Your character can fall through the floor, monsters fall from the sky randomly, playing at higher than 60 fps will cause your game to act weird, some areas will just make your game crash upon loading... I know that the mod "Skyrim unofficial patches" can be downloaded to fix some of these issues, but with the game as is, you are going to be annoyed really quickly with the tons of bugs you will encounter during your playthrough of the game. As for the overall performance, the game runs quite smoothly at 60 fps at least.   Story 9.2 The story is another very strong point of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Some questlines in particular will get you so addicted to the game, that you will play it through until it's done. The fact that almost all of your choices affects the outcome and scenario of almost every single quests is just crazy. The amount of work put into this aspect of the game is huge! You can be a good guy, a bad guy or simply do just what you want. A certain character annoys you? Kill him! You recovered a powerful artifact that somebody asked you to get for him? If you want to keep it, you can! That's how much you can control your character's fate.   Singleplayer 8.5 Well, since The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim only offers Singleplayer, this is just a resume of my review. The game is fun to play by yourself, it doesn't get boring at all and it's totally worth trying out. Just keep in mind, that bugs and crashes will affect your experience by a large margin unless you mod your game heavily. Even there, you might still experience some annoying bugs with mods, but it's definately gonna be better.   Multiplayer -- This game features no co-op or multiplayer.   Playtime 10 The game is known for excelling in this aspect. It took me 140 hours just to go through essensial parts of the game to complete all achievements. I have only done a few questlines and there's tons and tons of misc. quests that I have not started. Just in 1 playthrough you can spend from 100 to upward of 1000 hours depending on many quests you wanna finish, you many things you want to personally accomplish and if you want to craft full sets of gear, get to a very high level, unlock all magics, find all books, etc... Replayability is definately a strong point too! You can create a new character to try out a different race, look, build or just to re-do some questlines you might want to approach differently, because your choices in some quests will completely affect what happens during and after the quest.   Prices 9.0 For the amount of content and playtime this game offers, US$19.99 (As of late 2014) is a steal. Sure the DLCs are quite expansive, but if you get the Legendary Edition for US$39.99 you will get much more content and a better price than individual DLCs by far. This game is totally worth buying at the listed price.   Steam Features 10 It's got all the features you would hope for! The achievements in this game are super fun to work towards with only a few missable ones that you can easily manage to do if you read-up well enough before starting your game. It's got trading cards and most important, steam workshop support! As of late 2014, there are over 23,000 gameplay mods, items, quests, creatures... The list goes on. The modding community is extremely active for The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim! It's also got partial controller support and steam cloud.   Game Score 8.1   Information Hours Details   Time required to complete the game. ~30 hours. Main questline + few misc. quests and item farming.   Time required to fully complete the game. 1000+ hours. All quests + collect items + max level in all skills... Etc.   Time required to get 100% achievements in the game. ~140 hours. 75/75 achievements working, no particulary hard achievements.

content:
24, 2015
												Valve's Paid 'Skyrim' Mods Are A Legal, Ethical And Creative DisasterBy Paul TassiValve and Bethesda’s announcement of a jointly run paid Skyrim mods store has been met by nothing but fury from fans over the past 24 hours. Even modders, whom the idea is supposed to benefit, are coming out against the idea, which they deem detrimental to the entire community.It should be good news. Now modders have an official way to get paid through a partnership program when before most were getting nothing and many were squeaking by on a few donations alone. But in practice, Valve/Bethesda’s Skyrim mod store is an absolutely terrible idea for reasons that are already becoming clear even in the first day after launch. Let’s go through the issues fans and modders themselves are bringing up.The Split is UnreasonableThe modders only take home 25% of the money made from the sale of their mods. The rest is split in some undisclosed way between Valve and Bethesda. As Erik Kain pointed out yesterday, this is well below something like the Apple store, which gives creators at least 70% of the cash. Just 25% seems abysmally low. Even if it’s “better than zero” as proponents will claim, it’s more than a little reminiscent of Nintendo's we-don’t-understand-the-market YouTube policies which forced a revenue share program that most content creators couldn’t be bothered with.Modders are Friends, Not FoodMods have kept a game like Skyrim alive for years after many would have otherwise stopped playing. Bethesda is choosing to look at this like “why are these players not giving us more money?” rather than “wow, this is amazing advertising and community building for our franchise!” Modders usually love the games they mod, which is why they spend so much time on their creations. Changing the equation and turning them into employees is going to dishearten many of them, and attract the wrong sort of crowd.The Wrong Sort of CrowdA mod store like this has the potential to turn a game like Skyrim from “fun, infinitely modifiable sandbox adventure” to “Guinness World Record holder for most microtransactions.” It will create a flood of modders who aren’t the type of passionate players doing it “for the love of the game,” but rather people trying to reskin a sword and sell it for $5. The game could be overloaded with this kind of crap, and even if it’s all “optional,” it puts a black mark on the entire modding community.The Legal QuestionsAlready, one of the paid Skyrim mods has been taken down after one user claimed another user was selling it using animations that he had originally created in his own mod. The mod store seller claimed that Valve actually forbade him from contacting the original animator about using his work because of an NDA about the existence the store. And this is somebody who is actually well-meaning. The “wrong crowd” mentioned above could easily slide in and just start stealing other people’s work left and right and selling it on the store. I’ve already heard of modders taking down their mods rather than let them potentially be stolen and used for paid store offerings. Even if Valve has some sort of report system in place, it’s going to be a headache to sort through justified and unjustified claims based on who iterated off whose work and who has the rights to the original mod and so on and so forth. It’s a nightmare waiting to happen.Potentially Broken ProductsMods, are by definition, experimental. Though Steam has a 24 hour return policy for mods, so you can send something back (so to speak) if you don’t like it, there doesn’t seem to be anything in place to prevent a modder from selling something to consumers, having it break down the road, and then simply never fixing it, leaving the buyer with a useless piece of software they paid good money for. Most gaming companies don’t do this because they’re large organizations with reputations to uphold. But some modders might not care and be perfectly comfortable with abandoning a mod they can’t be bothered to fix. They and Bethesda and Valve already made their money when they sold it, and the return policy prevents further recompensation, so who cares? Let the consumer rant into the void about it.Dividing a CommunityThe Skyrim community has always been a pretty tight group, but now through the introduction of the store, a lot of tension has been created overnight. Fans are looking at modders like this was their idea as an attempt to cash in. Free modders are looking at paid modders as sellouts. Legitimate paid modders are looking at newbie paid modders as opportunists. It’s awful, and only made possible through the introduction of the store. Bethesda had a creative, united community until yesterday, and now there’s tons of infighting, not to mention the rage directed at the company itself.“Oh Someone Will Just Mod That”Here’s some fun with theoretical extrapolations of this concept. Let’s say that Bethesda wants to make another Skyrim DLC expansion involving some new order of warriors. They want to make their signature weapon a flail, but the oddly behaving weapon is proving difficult to animate and operate effectively on PC. Under this new system do they A) work really hard to get past the issue and release the flail at launch or B) say “oh the modders have flails, let’s just promote their mod in the store.” Under the old system, Bethesda would have been motivated to make the flail themselves, but under the new one, someone is doing it for them, and they’re taking up to 75% of the revenue for each flail sold. I’m not saying this would for sure be their philosophy going forward, but when a company can charge handily for someone adding extra content into their game, you can bet that the opportunity for exploitation is there.Honestly, all of these issues were just off the top of my head after glancing through a few forum posts about the store where fans are expressing similar concerns. There are probably many, many more issues no one has even considered yet. The pros are technically “modders get paid, the game maker gets paid,” but past that, there are too many cons to count.This will prove to be a disaster, and may damage the PC the modding community irreparably if the practice spreads.NOTE: Original article written by Paul Tassi, contributor to Forbes.

content:
3, 2014
												Skyrim (Base Game) - REVIEW What is there to say about this game? Where do I even begin to tackle this monstrosity that has taken me on my 1st playthrough 141 hours just to finish the Skyrim base-game? We're not enough counting the DLC's here...yet! The Elder Scrolls (TES) is 1 of those series that are loaded w/ tons + tons of content, offering up an insane amount of value + "bang for your buck". To experience all of it at once - IMHO, at least for me, that's probably not the wisest ideas. This game has so many different storylines, quests, areas to explore, factions, things to do (i.e. get married) - it's a game you play for numerous hours until you've hit that wall (i.e. "I need a break for a while"); just go away from for a bit; & then it calls you back for more. Very few games do this to me - Test Drive Unlimited 2; Far Cry 3; + Skyrim all come to my mind here.Class systems are gone here in Skyrim. Just practice the attributes you want to want to improve (i.e. sneak around, improve that skilll; swing a 1-handed sworded and hit someone, that improves; cast a spell from a certain school, that improves, etc); + select new abilities from those attributes to learn at level-up time. Since you're constantly improving your attributes + leveling-up like there's no tomorrow, this can be addictive - think like that Diablo-like kind of addictive.Skyrim has improved in numerous ways over its predecessor. Graphically, on the technical side, the game is much better than Oblivion. Girls actually do look more so like girls (in the face, namely), this time around - thanks for finally getting this right, Bethesda; it took you long enough! While many of the game areas are nowhere as crazy + interesting as Oblivion's Shivering Isles expansion (my favorite area in any TES game since starting in the series w/ Morrowind). These lands have a Nordic influence on them + most of them truly do look fantastic. Likely, if you see an area way out in the distance, there's a great chance - you can go there + explore it completely, which is fantastic.Combat here has improved & is a bit more visceral than Oblivion - but, when compared to others, it certainly is still a little bit clunky (like most TES games) + does not rival the combat of other games like Kingdom of Amalur: Reckoning + Dark Souls (those games certainly do specialize in combat) - it's still pretty good here in Skyrim. One thing that's new -  you can now dual-wield weapons; can even wield magic in one hand, a weapon in another; dual-wield different magic spells in each hands; and/or even dual-wield the same magic spell (for double the power). Simply put - these are great additions to this game's combat system.NPC's in the game-world actually have taken a page right out of the Gothic play-book, as you will see NPC's doing things to immerse you into the world - i.e. blacksmith sharpening blades with equipment; NPC's acting on schedules + doing things together on their own; + things of that natures. As usual, there's even more books added to read, for those who want to dwelve into the ever-expanded + ridiculously-sized Lore of the series. The main story here is this - dragons have returned to Skyrim, you're to meet a certain group of people to fulfill your destiny as the Dragonborn (a human that can learn dragon skills), learn Dragon-style shouts, & take the Dragons out once + for all - which is typical fantasy stuff. While the main quest is decent enough + is solid, it really feels like it's just another quest in the game - like many of the main quests in Elder Scrolls base-games since Morrowind. While Bethesda is no BioWare + no Obsidian when it comes to generating fantastic narrative, prose + dialogue - where Bethesda succeeds over just about every other of the game companies is creating insanely huge playgrounds that have a good deal normally going on w/ tons to accomplish, if you like what you're doing. Trust me - this is another addictive sandbox from Bethesda, in which you won't know how to let go of for a while or after being away for a while, it will eventually get you coming back for more. While not everything here is a home-run, there are also many good-to-great plots + storyline strings here - such as the Thieves Guild's quest-line + especially Dark Brotherhood quest-lines, that I don't even know where to begin. Skyrim will generate some random quests on its own, which often do wind-up in the Misc section - which could keep you going for a long time. As if the base-game couldn't do that enough already, making this game such a time-sink - throw in also that the game ships w/ the Toolkit these days & the ridiculous amount of mods out there b/c this series has an extremely heavy modding community + fanbase - you could live for 100's of hours in Skyrim, even long well after it takes finishing the insane amount of content that Bethesda has already provided. If there's something about Skyrim you don't like - i.e. the UI isn't that great, again; even though it's improved immensely over Oblivion - trust me, there's a mod out there to fix your issue w/ the game. For example - SkyUI Mod vastly improves + fixes Bethesda's UI-system immesely. By offering up a huge sandbox & an insane amount of things to do (from questing to exploring) here, Skyrim succeeds in proving again why Bethesda + their Elder Scrolls is 1 of the best - if not, the best - at providing addictive time-sink RPG's. Bethesda yet again offers up the kitchen sink here; I'll certainly drink to that + from that. RPG fans looking to get lost for 100's of hours, it's almost impossible to rival what Bethesda does in their games - & that's especially true here in Skyrim. Simply put - another RPG masterpiece from Bethesda.Final Grade = A+

												Skyrim is the best Elder Scrolls game so far, with the expansions it has gotten even better. I felt that ESIII: Morrowind brought more to the table for its time than ESIV: Oblivion but believe this game has done even more. I have enjoyed it on console, on PC and gone through the DLC which is worth the extra cash. The only thing missing is co-op/multi player but Elder Scrolls Online is running now, although I wish they would have done things a little differently on that game..Even if your not an Elder Scrolls fan or follower the game is a nice play as it allows you to customize yourself and play in many styles to allow a change up.I did have a few technical issues following the main quest line but just shifted to side quests and other things until I found out how to fix my save. They could have done a litle better on updating to debug some of the common issues or allowed a form of abandoning quests to reset them.Overall I'd say 9.5/10 for what it is as I can't complain about missing features that just weren't supposed to be in the game although I think they coulda just put out a co-op patch/expansion to allow us to play with 1 friend or something which would have enhanced the gameplay alot and expanded the games popularity.

content:
3, 2013
												I've been a fan of The Elder Scrolls series for a while, and I think Skyrim is definitely a worthy addition to that line of games. Skyrim is a huge, immersive, lore-filled, immense world full of character. You can explore, fight, collect, or just wander around like a tourist taking screenshots. Even after playing for a couple of years, I still constantly find new places to explore and new experiences to be had.Everything about this game is extremely detailed and well thought-out, from the crafting system to the player homes, from dungeon layouts, to the races of the different NPCs you encounter and the way they use their culture to express themselves in their clothing, armor, weapons, homes, and towns.If the hundreds of hours offered by the game itself isn't enough, there are literally thousands of mods for Skyrim, offering everything from texture enhancements to full cinematic lighting effects. There are hours and hours of additional fan-made quests and storylines, in addition to the three official DLC expansions offered by Bethesda. New NPCs, pets, followers, houses, towns, armor, weapons, food, ingredients -- you can probably find a mod to change or add to almost any aspect of Skyrim. In this way, you can keep the game fresh and new, even after hundreds of hours of play.If you break it down to dollars spent per hour played it's probably one of the best deals in gaming.

												Bueno, con casi 300 horas, y varias partidas que la gran mayoría nunca llegé a compeltarlas al 100%, pero esta última si, hago mi análisis personal, que no tengo intención para nada de hacerme el reviewer poniendo gráficos, sonido y todo eso porque no lo soy, sinó dar mi opinión y ya está.El juego en si me gustó, es LAAARGO, GRAAAANDE y JUGOSO (e.e) muchísimas horas si te dispones a explorar todo al 100%, y más aún en hacer las misiones secundarias también al 100%, contando las del Gremio de Ladrones, Hermandad Oscura, Los Compañeros, el Colegio de Hibernalia, cada una contando con su propia historia interesante interna (Mi favorita de todas son las de la Hermandad Oscura).El problema está, en que, aunque sea tan largo y grande el mapa con tantas misiones secundarias, a partir de cierto nivel se empieza a tornar muy repetitivo, al ya superar la "etapa de reto" que sería desde lvl 10-45, si es que no usaste una de las 1.000 maneras de conseguir armas daédricas rápidamente desde el comeinzo y ya tener el juego en tu bolsillo, al igual que los dragones, que los primeros son de verdad un reto e impresionan, pero ya cuando vas por el número 5 y ves que SIEMPRE hacen lo mismo, ese efecto se va rápido.Me gustaron más las misiones de las facciones que nombré antes, que la propia trama principal, y ni hablar de las de la guerra civil, que luego de acabarlas sientes que no cambió absolutamente nada en el juego, salvo algunas cosas que te repiten una y otra vez los NPC's al entrar en ciudades.En cuanto a los logros, saqué todos, no son difíciles para nada, sinó que lo "complicado" es que llevan tiempo y requieren atención A POSTA si se quieren conseguir algunos (El que más me costó fue el de matar a un Dragón Legendario, ya que salen solo a partir del nivel 78, y yo terminé el juego y todas sus misiones secundarias sienod lvl 60-65, pero con subir discreción, resetearla (se agradece que agregaran esa opción) y volverla a subir, bastó con media hora o 1 hora para logar subir esos niveles que faltaban. Al igual que el logro de hacer un objeto con el mineral del DLC Dragonborn, que si o si necesitabas Herrería a 80 y el perk de crear armaduras de ébano para poder hacerlo.Una de las cosas que tiene muy a favor el juego, es su grán comunidad de mods, tanto en Workshop como en Skyrim Nexus, una gama de mods gigante de distintos tipos y para todos los gustos (yo opté por los gráficos y poco más la verdad, no me gusta llenar de mods un juego hasta el punto que ya deja de ser Skyrim y se vuelve otra cosa, obviamente respeto al que lo haga, pero si tienes que llenar de mods un juego para que te guste.. Deh, para eso no lo jueges, no?.Un pequeño punto malo, que no es del juego sinó de los mods, es que pueden bugearte o cagarte misiones, como me pasó a mi con la Hermandad Oscura, que jamás apareció el ♥♥♥♥ mensajero que SI O SI tiene que darte una nota para comenzar la misión, hay formas de iniciarla igualmente con comandos en la consola, pero es inútil, ya que más adelante, al forzarla con la consola la misión, hay personajes que no aparece donde tendrían y bueno, pasa lo que pasa.Resumiendo todo el Corán que puse arriba, el juego me entretuvo porque son mi droga los juegos de exploración y con muchas misiones secundarias, pero en cuanto a historia principal tambalea y creo que mucho, siento que todas las cosas que hago durante el juego apenas influyen en Skyrim más que en diálogos forzados o situaciones que hsata me dan verguenza ajena como me tratan de restregar las cosas que hago para hacerte sentir "Hey, salvaste el mundo!" y todos cojiendo en las granjas sin siquiera saber que Alduiun casi se los viola, tiene demasiada fama el juego, y por lo único que lo disfruté es por la enormidad del mapa, el Lore de los dragones, los Dwemers y los Elfos de las Nieves (Falmers) Por eso es que disfruté más la trama de los DLC's que la del propio juego (Salvo la misión del "Muro de Alduin" la parte donde Esbern narra todo, es lo único que en serio me interesó profundamente de todas las misiones primarias, además del asunto de los Thalmor.Es un poco triste que me haya atrapado más esas historias internas que salen en libros o en misiones secundarias, que la propia trama principal en si misma. (Tengo que aclarar que los libros son CIENTOS y algunos son de verdad HERMOSOS porque te cuentan cosas que el juego creo que ni siquiera tendría las herramientas para hacerlo).Recomiendo comprarlo cuando esté en rebaja, el precio de los DLC's me parece exageradísimo para   lo que duran jajaja, aunque la historia para mi valiera la pena de los 2.

content:
9, 2016
Product received for free
												The Elder Scrolls, Bethesda's flagship series, is a true gem in the RPG genre. I'm well-versed in other games, such as The Legend of Zelda, Dragon's Dogma, etc., but they really don't compare to The Elder Scrolls (TES). The five main games in The Elder Scrolls franchise are all really spectacular, although it's hard to go back and play the old ones after experiencing the new ones. I currently own the entire series in a box set, with all DLC, and maps for each area featured in each game, including a map of the continent, Tamriel, so you COULD say I'm kind of a geek.Okay, enough babbling. I'm going to focus on Skyrim in particular now, as it's the object of my review. I will not say I have gotten or ever will get the full Skyrim experience. The game is simply massive. While you can play the main storyline, the numerous side quests, and all of the DLC, but there are still hundreds of locations you'll never go to in the game. I first played the game on PlayStation, and probably had a few hundred hours in before my PlayStation 3 committed suicide. Rest in peace.I eventually re-purchased the Legendary Edition (aka, all-DLC-for-the-price-of-base-game edition) for Xbox 360. I wasn't really satisfied with my experience, but at least I had a cool map of Skyrim. Later, for my birthday (or perhaps Christmas), I received the Elder Scrolls Anthology, the aforementioned box set which completed my life. This allowed me to redeem a Steam code for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim, with all addons included. This experience was satisfying for three main reasons: the graphics/performance, the gameplay, and finally the modding capability.GraphicsThose of us in the PC Master Race probably know the power of a PC well out-maneuvers that of a console, especially the last generation. Skyrim on BOTH PS3 and Xbox 360 was probably running at a "cool" 30 frames per second or so, and still looked like literal ♥♥♥♥. Naturally, my ultra-powerful gaming PC, with a super speedy Core2 Quad and high-powered GTX 660 outperformed the console by a million miles. What I'm getting at, if you didn't catch my sarcasm, is that Skyrim does not require a PC on steroids, and the game will still give you gorgeous visuals on any card you might have shoved into your motherboard. The game still holds up to today's visual standards despite being made in 2012, and if you have a mid-to-low range build like I do, then Skyrim is perfect for you.GameplaySkyrim is one of those games where you can easily become your character. Obviously, the world of Nirn doesn't exist, and humans can't launch fireballs at each other or shoot lightning out of their fingertips (except in a galaxy far, far away). But, being a nearly god-like character, you sometimes get too much into what you're actually doing. Okay, let's talk about gameplay factors that help with this immersive feeling. Leveling is important. If you've ever played Fallout 3, 4, or New Vegas, then you know that XP is earned by completing missions, killing enemies, and successfully hacking or lockpicking something. Upon leveling up, you are allocated a perk point to spend on a perk. Your character also has the "SPECIAL" attributes, which influence the numerous skills in the game. Skyrim, however, has a much simpler, and much more beautiful way of going about this. You level up your skills by using those skills. Realistic! I lockpick a door? Lockpicking XP for me! The skills level up as you use them, and part of this XP benefits your overall level. Higher skill levels unlock more perks, which are purchased upon leveling up. This is all done in a beautiful skill tree screen, in which the skill trees are, in fact, constellations. This system gives you complete control over your character, allowing you to define a certain class to fit into or even to pursue all skills equally.Combat and the inventory system are also pretty important for your gameplay experience. Combat is very fluid, and there are so many ways to approach it. You can fight up close with melee weapons, light or heavy, dual-wielded or held with a shield. You can go at it from range, with magic or bows and arrows, or avoid it altogether and sneak past your enemies, slitting their throats as you pass by. Or you can do a combination. This freedom to choose your approach to any situation makes Skyrim a fantastic and very personalized experience.The inventory is a great piece of work. TES IV:Oblivion had a messy, hard-to-navigate UI. There were tabs with pictures and it was just so hard to figure anything out. Skyrim, on its Character Menu, however, has easily identified areas for magic, your map, your inventory, and your skills, each with levels of organization within.ModdingThe kind old folks over at Bethesda are very generous to us gamers. Some time after they released Skyrim, they released the Skyrim Creation Kit, a full suite of tools very similar, if not identical to what was used to make the game in the first place. This power allows players like you and me, provided we have knowledge of the Creation Engine, to make our own content for Skyrim. This means Skyrim is automatically a million times larger than it was before. Do you want Skyrim's lighting to have an overhaul? Done. Do you want the harsh conditions of a cold, northern state to have a real and terrifying effect on your character? Done. Are you simpler, and just want more swords, axes, and armor? Done. Or maybe you think the top of that barrel looks too decagon-y? That can be fixed. Oh, or maybe you've got some fancy hardware and you want every texture in the game to be in 4k? Done. Mods open up thousands of new possibilities that the devs didn't have time for originally, and can also fix mistakes in the game through giant unofficial patches.Final WordSkyrim? More like SkyWOW. 9.7/10I apologize for that. That was just plain awful.By the way, if you like reading my walls of text and you actually laugh at some of my humor, consider reading more of my reviews of other games to see if my interpretation makes that one tough decision for you!

content:
r 30, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a 2011 fantasy role-playing game that critics and players raved the game with great awe. Since the game was released, Skyrim still managed to be on the top most-played game on Steam. With a large area to explore, so many quests to do, or just do the heck you want, should you get the PC version of Skyrim?Skyrim is one of those games that you can “skim” through the main story and then play a different game, completed parts of the main story then you forget about it, do side and miscellaneous quests, or explore the world on your own with massive amounts of hours dumping in into this strangely addicting game. There’s a good chance that the player would have more than 100 hours on Skyrim and still have plenty things to do. You start off as a prisoner bound to be executed until a dragon shows up and the people of Skyrim went wild that the dragons have returned. As I’m writing down this review, I am not halfway through the main story and that might be the point. Skyrim is a game that you’ll probably not going to finish the main story since Skyrim has so many things to do. Like the previous Elder Scrolls titles beforehand, the game is immersive and sucks you in. The side quests are pretty solid like the Companions, the Dark Brotherhood, and among many others. What separates the PC version from the Xbox 360 and the PS3 are the mods. That’s right: M.O.D.S. Mods can extend the replay value to almost infinity and there’s a good chance that you find a mod (or mods) that you are looking for.1. Do you want to visually overhaul the graphics from the vanilla version to ultimate high definition graphics? There is. 2. Do you want mods that enhance your immersion up to the next level? There is. 3. Do you need community-made patches for Skyrim that Bethesda Games Studios forget about? There is. 4. Do you want to find mods that remodel the female body structures to something attractive, beautiful, and probably lusty? There is. 5. Do you want to find mods that remodel the female followers and companions like Serana, Aela the Huntress, Mjoll the Lioness (along with plenty others) to beautiful and s*xy, and you say to yourself: “Hot d*mn, I love Skyrim mods!”? H*ll yeah there is!There are two mod managers: the Steam Workshop and Nexus Mods. I strongly recommend to use Nexus Mods since Nexus has a lot more to offer than Steam Workshop (for obvious reasons). Once you mod Skyrim with visual overhauls or retexturing female followers, there’s no going back. Arguably, this is the best part for the PC version of Skyrim and I’m glad that Bethesda has giving modders the tools to create such imaginative mods.Is there some flaws or criticism for the game that is universally well-recognized, won multiple Game of the Year Awards in 2011, and still considered as one of the most played games on Steam? Every game has some flaws and it’s not perfect. The dialogue writing is decent in most cases, but it should have been better. Some quests in Skyrim feel “short” like the Companions side quests/plot as an example. I terribly missed the Fighter and Mages Guilds from the previous Elder Scroll titles. If you played the quests from the previous titles, the plot in each guild is pretty solid and gives you a good amount of hours to do. Miscellaneous quests in Skyrim are mostly fetch the required items and returned to the quest giver and there are a lot of those quests. Bethesda has a reputation for not fixing some of the major bugs and no longer supporting the game to fix these issues, allowing the community to nitpick and hunt every possible bug that Bethesda failed to address or didn’t bother to do so.  The criticisms for Skyrim are relatively minor and doesn’t affect the immersion very much. The only possible concern is how Bethesda deals with mods in future titles (like Fallout 4, which we will have to be cautious on Bethesda’s moves). Other than these entanglements, Skyrim is a great game and the mods definitely makes a difference. With Skyrim installed, you will end up having one of the greatest adventures in your lifetime. With mods installed, you are in virtual reality.

y 16, 2015
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim	Play as the Dovakiin and fufill your prophecy and do some side quest while you're at it, in the world of Skyrim. Disclaimer	I have played this game a lot on console, around an estimated 200hrs therefore please don't take my Steam hours into account. I will also be mentioning modifications a lot into this review, as even Bethesda accepts, mods have become a stable for their games and this game is no expection. I fully recommend you check out the Nexus[www.nexusmods.com] (hub for all mods) and some YouTube videos to fully show you how customizable this game truely is. The modding community in this game is insane and deserves as much credit as possible.Pros:- Fantastic modding community. Range of mods that you can find which have been made over the years down from graphics mods to armor mods. The amount of mods are insane, at this stage you can create your own game with the amount of mods available. If anything takes to your dislike in the game, you can easy just modify the game to your standards.- The graphics have aged extremely well. The scenery of the game is breathtaking at times.-  Intresting storyline and plenty of intriguing side quests you can follow with different factions. - Character customization. This feature allows you to create your own legacy and roleplay as your character (if you're into that thing) and along with mods, fully customize your characters looks. - Gameplay is fun. Exploring is a major gameplay element in this game. Combat can be a little clunky, however offers a great range of approaches on how you want to kill enemies, spells, swords, etc.- Immersive, the game allows you to bond with the world of Skyrim. On the single note of immersion, you should buy this game.- The game offers hours of content in the vanilla game itself. You surely get your money worth out of the time you play in the vanilla game. Mods also create hours of fun with custom quests, etc.- The DLC is quality in this game. The DLC is classic, just adds new quests and items with a small price.Cons:- Many characters share the same voice actors. This can be a shame at times, but acceptable and doesn't destory the game at any cost. Nothing that mods can't fix. - Difficulty in this game is a joke. Please download some challenging mods in this game to create a challenge for yourself.- The game is really slow to get into in the beginning. I recommend you finish the main quest or get halfway through before deciding if you like this game or not. The main quest itself isn't long, it's the side quests which make up the hours.Conclusion:Just buy this game, do yourself a ♥♥♥♥ing favor.

												Skyrim is easily one of the best games of this generation. It’s one of the games that you get as much out of as you put in. It’s also one of the games you play exactly how you want to play. You can choose to ignore the main story immediately after beginning or play through the quests like a linear action adventure game. Speaking of quests, there’s an awful lot of them.The main story is centred on the return of dragons to the world. Pretty soon, you find out you are the legendary Dragonborn, a man or woman with the ability to consume dragon souls. It’s your job to find out why the reptiles have returned and try and protect the world from this new menace. two thumbs from me! because the game deserves it.

												I don't care what anyone says, Skyrim is one of the greatest games I have EVER played, I have dedicated SOOO much time into it, (Yes i know on my profile it says I haven't played it for all THAT long but I never really played it while connected to the internet so yeah) There was a time when I would play skyrim for close to 12 hours a day (yep sure did take my life away from me) It was actually my very first steam game. After dedicating even more time in TES IV Oblivion, I eventually got Skyrim in 2012 and I will admit that after creating all kinds of characters I did eventually get tired of it, that was until I discovered MMOxReview on Youtube (Great guy, check him out :)) I then started modding my skyrim game, and a once Great game turned into something legendary... Now to be honest I wasn't all THAT fond of the Main quest, BUT the thieves guild and Dark brotherhood in these games has always really inspired me, I just wish they could have made them both longer :( Unfortuantly I have never played the expansions for Skyrim seeing as though I can't afford it :( Yeah i know, sad isn't it, But that hasn't stopped me from playing Skyrim over and OVER again... TES Online... let's just say I probs will never play it because I just don't really like the looks of it. And I am VERY keen for TES VI (I think it is going to be set in Hammerfell) Please tell me if you would like me to write a guide for this game, I am quite happy to and I promise I won't use any of that noob language if i do. I highly recommend this game, I give it a score of 9.5/10 Have a nice day ;)

number of helpful: 23 of 33 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2014
												There are many reasons why we play games. Some play games to experience a story, some play to compete with others and some play to have experiences they have never had otherwise in real life. Alot play games to escape into another world, and live completely different lives, and this is what drives Bethesda’s Elder Scrolls series, a series that has excelled in creating complete virtual worlds, inviting the player to live parallel lives. Skyrim is the latest world offered by Bethesda to live in, and it seems like its Bethesda’s finest accomplishment yet.Similarly to the two Elder Scrolls games before it, you start off as a prisoner, and this case you are on your way to be executed. Just before the axe greets your neck, a dragon appears and the entire army base you were in goes into disarray. You are set free after the incident, and it is up to you to find out why are the dragons appearing, and what is your role in the whole ordeal (hint: it rhymes with Shmagonborn).Bethesda displays such dedication to concept of open world that makes other open world games pale in comparison. Skyrim isn’t just a series of buildings, environments and NPCs, it is the closest there is to virtual living world in a game. The sense of freedom found in Elder Scrolls is unparalleled, and Skyrim is the best implementation of this yet. The main quest is a minimal part of the game, and most of the fun comes from exploring the world built for you. As you go exploring dungeons, assisting NPCs with their problems, joining factions and reading ingame books, you realize what a dense world Skyrim is. It is compelling to learn more about Skyrim, about its citizens and about its politics, and the more you learn about, the more you are invested in the well being of the world.Through all the running around and exploring, you come across a wide range of missions to complete. The main mission is, as usual, the most interesting one, but the rest of the missions can be worthy, and they are necessary to help you know more about the world. You can complete missions for The Companions (Skyrim’s equivalent of the Fighter’s Guild) to understand how ingrained the warrior culture is in Skyrim, or join the Mages College and be looked down upon by Nords who believe that magic is for sissies. Even miscellaneous missions, such as simply standing up for a Dark Elf against a bunch of racist Nords can be satisfying. Standard fetch quests are to be found here and there, but there are far from being the norm.The games graphics have been talked about endlessly. Now, Skyrim’s graphics are great, with detailed textures and wonderful environments. Yet it terms of detail, they don’t hold a candle to games like Rage and Battlefield 3. Yet Skyrim is nicer to look at than the aforementioned games, and that is because of Skyrim’s aesthetics. Bethesda knows that when it comes to graphics, art direction trumps fidelity, and in Skryim, the beauty of the world comes from its style. Part of the reason Morrowind is generally viewed as a much better game than Oblivion is because of its fantastical designs; while Oblivion came off as a standard European fantasy setting, Morrowind was a truly outlandish and exotic location that had its own unique identity. Skyrim returns with the art direction that made Morrowind so unique. While the location might not be as exotic as Morrowind, Skyrim it is exactly the blistering norse region that you would think is occupied by burly, war-faring people. The buidlings, the environments, the apparel, the weapons, the creatures, and even the music all give Skyrim its unique identity, an identity that is inspired by real-life Scandinavia, but is in no way identical to it.–~~~~~~~~~~~~– The combat, which is one of the weaker aspects in previous Elder Scrolls, is drastically improved here. While there is still the feeling that you are hacking away at empty spaces instead of making a real impact on your enemy, but it’s not as bad as it was in previous games. The biggest addition to the combat system is the double wielding, and it works great. You can go for a sword in each hand, a sword and spell, or two spells, one in each hand. I personally went sword and staff, Gandalf style. There is also a favorite menu for items, a feature that pauses makes it easier to equip items in game. This is designed to save you the hassle of going to the main item screen during the game, but it also gives a tactical quality to the combat, since the menu pauses the game and allows for quick equipment changes, which is helpful especially when fighting dragons.Dragons appear as random encounters throughout the game, and they are just as imposing as one would imagine dragons to be. You will die alot fighting them, and you would have to rely on myriad of tactics to fight them. A few hacks there, retreat to heal yourself, attack with destruction magic while the dragon is airborne, retreat again, and so on. Killing a dragon is immensely satisfying, and through killing dragons do you acquire new ‘shouts’. Shouts are another new combat feature; they are words in the dragon language which, when you say them, unleashes different attacks on your enemies, or gives you new powers. Shouts are a welcome addition to the game’s combat system, and further adds to the combat’s tactical quality.Now this is a Bethesda game, which means that bugs are abound. I have experienced a few unresponsive actions from NPCs, same crashes, and an axe suspended in midair. However, this is an area I can’t criticize Bethesda much about. In a game of this size and scope, it is virtually impossible to spot all the bugs before release. To their credit, Bethesda is quick to releases patches that fix whatever issues gamers may have. We can also count on the mod community to tweek all the inconveniences out of the game. Bugs are abundant in the game, and players will experience at least one in every playthrough, yet for the most part, these bugs are miniscule and far from game breaking.Skyrim is like a music album that has a few tracks that you aren’t particularly fond of, but rest of the music is pure aural blliss that you can’t help but think of the album as close to perfection as possible. I can’t point to a single part of the game and say “that is the best part”; the entire game is an experience. It stays firmly rooted in Elder Scrolls gameplay, yet with enough improvements and additions (and subtractions) to make Skyrim stand on its own. After experiencing the vast, dense and incredibly detailed world of Skyrim, you can’t help but snicker whenever another game is referred to as “open world”.   Good: Vast yet incredibly detailed world, Incredible Depth, Interesting Story, Improved Combat System, Gorgeous Graphics and wonderful styleBad: Buggy, some standard 'fetch' missionsPrice: AED 9.5/10

r 9, 2016
												This game is the closest thing to my favourite game of all time. What i mean by that is, i find the quesiton itself unfair. It is like asking which is your favourite child. Answering it is missing the point. Having sed that, this game for me is a bit like falling in love, i am drawn to it and just makes me happy. The game is a roleplayign system at its hearth. Want to be a mage user with swords? Go for it. Archer with swords ? Go for it. Mage that conjures monsters to fight for him ? Go for it. ALL of that? GO FOR IT. Just play the game, and you will be who you want to be. The World, the lore , the quets are just amazing. Now to be fair, taken apart peace by peace Skyrim is not exceptional , the combat is just fine, the story is just fine, the visuals i think are amazing but some would say are just good, (the music is excellent though), But when all the peaces are put together in one game, it is a MASTERPICE of an experience. It is a classic that will stand up FOREVER. I rarely gush so openly about anything but this is my one exception. The Elder scrolls seres is near and dear to my hearth, and as much as i love the other games in their own way aswell, skyrim is by statiscits(times i played and options it gives)  the best Elder scrolls game. Maybe in the future the next one TES 6 will suppas it, it maybe will. But even then, some will say Skyrim was the best , same way some say Oblivion is, or Morrowind. In a way, everyone is right, these games are special, let us not fight over whos better, but enjoy that they exist, and the passion people have for them. Just play this game, it is one of my most trusted firends in games. I hope i will always come back to it . :)19.2.2017

content:
27, 2015
												This is my third review of this game, the second was prompted by the atrocity of locking mods behind a paywall, but as Valve and Bethesda realized the error of their ways, I will upload a new positive review.Core Skyrim, released 11-11-11, was a tremendous addition to the storied Elder Scrolls franchise that I had enjoyed since Daggerfall (which is still installed on my system and which I still play from time to time!). The DLCs were so-so, Hearthfire being my favorite of the three; but the mods and the modding community were what made this the premeir experience in PC gaming. I play Skyrim using 3D glasses and headphones and with the amazing mods like Frostfall, Wet and Cold, Immersive HUD, realistic needs and diseases, and Hunterborn it felt as if I was really there in Skyrim! With my role playing and dead-is-dead playstyle it was truly a magical experience, fulfilling the promise of video games that was only hinted at when I saw Dragon's Lair in the arcade as a child.This game was worth it at full price, and today is a "must own" when you can snag it on sale for 15 bucks or less! I have subscribed to Nexus in the past for mods, and will do so again, usually when I plan on playing Skyrim heavily for a month or more. I will now start to support modders ranging from a few cents to a few dollars depending on the amount I use it and the quality. What Valve, Bethesda and Nexus need to do is sit down and really hammer out a user friendly donation system. I want to be able to donate directly from my Steam Wallet or a Nexus Wallet with a minimal number of clicks. As it stands, it is a hassle to throw a few pennies at a mod and when I am trying to relax after a harrowing day at work, I don't want to fill out a bunch of forms! If Valve, Bethesda and Nexus need to take a tiny slice (5% max) of that donation to offset the cost of that system, I am OK with that.Finally, three and a half years into its lifespan, Bethesda is prepping to announce Fallout 4 and we are going to start the long march to Elder Scrolls 6! What should the future hold? Bethesda needs to think big: the Elder Scrolls Online was a failure not because of what it was, but because of what it wasn't. People want a co-op Skyrim experience not an MMO. Even now, Bethesda could and should realease a no more than 10$ co-op DLC for Skyrim, or at least get the ZeniMax lawyers to stop embargoing modders who have gotten to the prototype stage of development. Imagine traversing the vast lands (and seas!!) of all of Tamriel as the inevitable war between mankind and the Thalmor erupts across the continent and perhaps the entire world of Nirn and beyond!This is where Bethesda needs to get the modding scene right! Bring those who want to do this for a living and parcel out sections of Nirn to them so they can build it to completion as formal, supported and integrated DLC! Imagine a seemless world where you and you good friends can campaign in full virtual reality! We should work to rebuild the community and to fulfill the promise hinted at by Skyrim!- Thank you!

												[Review written in Bahsa Indonesia]Saya bermain TES Skyrim kurang lebih 2 Tahun, 1 Tahun bermain game bajakannya, dan setelah awal Januari saya mengenal "Steam" saya mulai bermain dengan game originalnya, memang tidak ada yang berbeda, tapi sistem achievment yang selalu memberitahukan progress story kita untuk pamer ataupun mencari point dalam memainkan suatu game membuat saya tertarik untuk membeli game ini.Bethseda merupakan salah satu developer game yang saya rasa hebat karena membiarkan para player dan modder untuk me-remake habis game ini tanpa ada batasan apapun, entah itu mod yang mengandung unsur sara ataupun membuka aurat.Saya merasa sangat enjoy dengan game ini karena tidak hanya dari story yang menarik, namun game ini juga menyediakan berbagai macam fitur unik yang selalu RPG lovers impikan, yaitu First-Person View, Open-World, dan juga karakter yang kita bisa dandani sendiri. Jujur saja saya tidak terlalu melakukan Main Objective di game ini, saya hanya berjalan jalan saja untuk membuka semua marker di map dan juga mencari pemandangan untuk dibuat foto, dan terkadang saya juga lebih sering untuk modding karakter ketimbang memburu Naga.2 tahun berlalu sejak modding menjadi suatu aktivitas yang mengasikan hingga datanglah hari ini dimana Valve atau Steam, membuat fitur baru untuk menjual mod, ya, Menjual Mod. Saya mengecek beberapa mod yang saya endorse dan download, beberapa diantaranya sudah di Hidden atau bahkan di Remove oleh para pembuatnya. Setelah berkeliling sebentar, mod mod tersebut nongol di Steam Workshop dengan harga yang sangat tidak masuk akal, atau bahkan bukan pembuatnya yang memasang harga, tetapi orang yang baru saja bermain Skyrim dan meng-upload mod orang lain, saya cukup prihatin akan hal ini, dengan sistem baru dari Steam ini saya menjadi enggan bermain game ini lagi, Sudah cukup mengeluarkan biaya untuk membeli base game dan juga DLC dari game ini, Mengapa mod lebih mahal dari pada Main Files-nya ?

content:
24, 2015
												If I were to write a full review of this game, it would be nearly novel length. I would discuss all of the faults and failings of Skyrim, of how Bethesda took the generic route for more profit while selling out essentially everything that made Elder Scrolls worth playing, all while butchering the lore to cover their changes.Classes, a starting birth sign, the total nerf of all things magic, things like hand to hand being rolled into perks, the removal of stats, a whole class of armor being removed, reduction of armor pieces, the lies about spears, the broken marriage system, the dull civil war, the normalizing, and thus dulling effect on battling dragons, lore and plot hiccups and so much more could be covered.But instead, I can summarize it all with one message; I only bought this game because it could be modded. Really, the only reason why I even have well over 1000 hours in Skyrim is because of mods. On its own, even without ripping into every flaw, mistake, horrible design choice, the mountain of bugs and the aging engine that they still haven't bothered to work out flaws like the stuttering, Skyrim is not worth playing for more than a few hours. It holds no merit on its own, other than being open to modding.People can disagree, of course. There are a lot of people who still play it to this day on consoles, without the ability to mod. To them, I do not ask why, because it would solve nothing. I would still disagree with them. To me, this game is a flawed mockery of Elder Scrolls and the only thing that saved it is the modding community.I hold no hope for the future of Elder Scrolls, not after this game, and not after the way Bethesda so causally almost destroyed the community with their greed.

content:
er 25, 2013
												This game is not a "love it or hate it", it's a "love it AND hate it". Sometimes while playing I think to myself: "This is THE game, it's just a dream come true, is it real?", but the next moment it might change to: "This is the most stupid waste of time I've ever paid for". First of all, it is HUGE. It is enormous. I've done 300 hours into it and I'm still in the middle of the main quest. It's got everything: fights, spells, potions, horses, dogs, children, marriages, dragons, clothes, bookcases, treasure maps, grocery stores, pagan worshipping, war, armageddon, waterbreething, dead naked sorceresses in bikinis, mysterious ancient civilisations, glowing mushrooms, mammoths, zombies and lots, lots, lots of bugs. It is very beautiful, especially at night, when you see the northern lights shining, but also very ugly when the low and high resolution textures are messing up in front of you.  It's got so many quests, tasks, characters and places, I think even developers don't know them all. It is a gem for those who like to explore and discover the territory for themselves. Each cave has something in it, each ruin might conceal a secret, each village might have a mystery to uncover. The freedom of choice given to the player is unnatural. You can be a werewolf, a vampire, a mage, a warrior, an archer, a thief, an assassin, a blacksmith, a miner, an alchemist, on top of the dragonslayer and The Chosen One, and most of that you can be at the same time. This schizophrenic development of the character results in a no less chaotic gameplay. You have swords, bows, daggers, maces, spells, magic staffs, magic scrolls, and dragon shouts, all of which you can use as weapons. You meet all sorts of enemies and you're free to deal with them by any means you prefer. There is no special weapon for a giant. You don't really have to use spells against a mage. Moral choices are also a blur. There is no "proper" or "right" way, really, you just do stuff and get stuff happen as a result. It's not a bad thing to use conjuration spells, necromancy is not punishable, poisons are as legal as healing potions, there is no white or black magic. Sometimes it's impossible to understand if you're doing good or bad. I think the only thing that stops freedom from being absolute is the quests. If developers would remove the quest lines as such, turning them into a mass of random tasks you can perform in any sequence, at any time (and preferably at any place with any character), it would make the game a triumph of freedom (and a complete mess). So, Skyrim is a beautiful, ugly, strict, messy, very stupid and very clever game, which everyone should play at least once. On the easy level it is almost casual, no effort is required to deal with the fights. It can be played on a Mac through Crossover.

content:

												Skyrim, a game about adventure and saving the world from the evil dragons. Sounds pretty mediocre right? Well, no, the main storyline is surprisingly remarkable, since it ties well with the lore from the previous games to make you understand what makes it special. You can also shape what your character is, with a selection of unique races and playstyles. No wait, scratch that, YOU can make any playstyle that you want. Want to be a cat that destroys people with his fists? Go ahead! Wanna make an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ NPC get killed by all the guards in a hold? Why the hell not! What people really like in Skyrim though, is the gameplay and the mods that improve it. Let me put it this way, Skyrim is about the journey, not the destination. And having mods such as Frostfall and Duel Combat Realism makes playing the game all the more worthwhile. You can literally complete all the quests available and not be bored with the game. Proof? Look at the average of 10,000 people playing the game everyday, which, more than 50% of them, have been playing for years. So, in summary, this game is no doubt one of the best games of all time, and I definitely will continue playing it.

content:
24, 2015
												Like most Bethesda games, Skyrim is only mediocre when played without mods. With mods, the games cool factor rises a million times over. Mods let you change almost every element of the game, adding immeasurable fun, and replay value.  With that said, this is going to be a negative review because Bethesda, and Valve, have enabled a system where modders can now sell their mods on Steam. This act has already led to some modders pulling their mods from free sites like Nexus. Why is it a bad thing for modders to be paid for their work? Because that's not what modding is all about. I also mod, but I would never charge someone for something that is essentially done for fun, and with the notion of sharing with others. Modding has always been something done by the fans of a game, for other fans of the game. For companies like Steam, and Bethesda, to try to monetize that, is nothing more than greed. And get this, the modders only recieve 25% of what they charge for their mods. Guess who gets the other 75%. This move sets a really bad precedent for things to come. You may not play Skyrim, but what if Valve started doing this to all their games? Modders for all games could potentially start charging people, and then the whole modding community would just turn into a huge market that nets big money for greedy corporations.  So, though I had fun with it in the past, I do not recommend Skyrim to anyone. It's your call to get it, but when the only thing that makes the game any good, is about to become paid DLC, that's when the game turns foul in my mind.

content:
, 2015
 The Elder Scrolls V - Skyrim Name - SkyrimGenre - RPGPersonal Opinion - Easily one of the best RPG's out there As before, the time stated on this review is not true, I must have at least 500 offline hours on Skyrim Review The Elder Scrolls V - Skyrim, a game where you can be almost anything you want, if want to be a thief, then join the Thieves Guild! If you have a penchant for magic or the dark arts, join the Mages College, or if you prefer assassinating people for fun money, The Dark Brotherhood beckons you!You can do so many things in Skyrim, you can become a Vampire, a Werewolf or just be the dragon slaying badass you were meant to be!Like any open world high fantasy RPG it's a great game but the flaws are mostly held to heart by console peasants gamers who demand shiny things to be flawless. However, it is not flawless as glitches are common as they were in the previous games. It's almost becoming a 'style' in the Elder Scrolls series to have games that are so full of bugs that ant eaters are circling Bethesda studios as we speak. But bugs aren't that bad some can be funny and some even make you laugh for hours on end!This game is more engaging than a lock on a public bathroom. Once started you have a rather generic high fantasy experience of running around figuring out what's worth stealing and what's not. After a while though you might tire of the combat and fetch'em'all missions and then you start another character.Who or what you start as in Skyrim matters little, who you’ll become means everything. So it doesn't matter if you’re a local Nord, an Argonian, or an Orc. It doesn't matter if you’re partial to axes, arrows, or great balls of fire. It doesn't matter  if you’re driven by your storyline destiny, or driven to explore, sooner or later you are going to find out that every path WILL lead you to distraction, sometimes a quick and easy looking quest will turn into a 2 hour long expedition into a huge underground cavern, or just give you a nice surprise in the form of treasure! content:
27, 2015
												The whole idea of selling mods in a game is.... beyond exorbitant. Especially a single player game like Skyrim. Valve, you crossed the line. Here are some clearly addressed counterarguments for "why Valve should relinquish this pay-for-your-mods system"If a user creates a mod, they should make it not for the money, but for the whole gaming community and/or for experience. If money is the issue for the modder, then let's face it: they shouldn't be modding just for the sake of acquiring money. However, compensation for work shouldn't be disregarded: a donation system should be set up for the modders.A paid mod (like dlc) already establishes a new ground between players who can purchase the mod and players who can't. In game type (MMORPGs) this would be admissible, or (insert any multiplayer game within the given parameter). The mods would travel through some kind of quality control and then valve would sell it. However... Skyrim isn't even an MMORGP. It's a singleplayer game. For gods sake, you can't even play this game with other people, and a vast quantity of mods (in the payment section of the workshop) show that there really isn't a quality control.So far the aftermath of the implementation of this new system has caused modders in nexus to either: 1) take down their work on nexus and sell it here 2) take it down for the sake of preventing people from stealing it.  Shall I go onto nexus (or some other modding website), and sell it here as my own? Maybe use someone else's mod as a base for mine and sell it? This system really makes it easy to steal other people's work, re-brand it and sell it here for a profit. To steal a mod is very disrespectful to the original author(s) of the mod. This prevents new content from great modders being produced and released in fear of it being stolen. Also, Anyone who takes part of purchasing misappropriated mods will encourage and be apart of this larceny.Oh, what am I saying? Valve and Bethesda are going to take a 75% cut anyways.If you don't think this is a big deal, then think about this: In the near future, this whole system could spread to other games, not just Skyrim.

content:
24, 2015
												After Valve and Behesda introduced payware mods which opened a can of worms, I can no longer recommend this game. Paywalling mods is not the way to go as it introduces too many complex issues into the modding community that brings no benefits to anyone other than the Valve and Bethesda's pocket filled with money. I support the idea of getting the modders paid for their hard work in enriching the games but putting a paywall is not the right way. I support donations for modders as it is fairer as everyone has different level of perceived value for something. The only scenario I support paid mods is when a mod had done exceptional work where it can be essentially a full game or an official expansion with fair amount of new content and reasonable price tag, such as Age of Empires 2's Forgotten Empires mod that became an offical expansion. I would gladly pay for exceptional mods such as C&C Generals Rise of the Reds, Dawn of War's Ultimate Apocalypse or Homeworld 2's Complex mod as these teams had outdone what the developers had done with the original game and also provided a fresh and vastly expanded experience to the game. A sword or a handful of quests in Skyrim does not provide the fresh experience like those mods mentioned above. Not to mention the absurd price that they are selling mods for which costs as much as the game itself.Valve and Bethesda, you ducked it all up. Valve really needs to get their crap together with progressively worse server connection, Greenlight flooding the market with garbage, Steam Store that acts like an annoying sales man shoving garbage at you everyday, client stability that is getting worse and non existent customer server. At the same time, Valve is becoming increasingly more and more greedy to the point they even outdo EA, Ubisoft, 2K and the lot of greedy publisher. "You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain." Harvey Dent, The Dark Knight

er 15, 2011
												Skyrim is the perfect example of how a vast and addictive adventure game is done, without overloading the player with Witcher-like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ complexity.  You begin the game picking only your race and from then, what type of fighter you are is completely built off of how you play, making for endless possibilities of the fighter you can become.  It is a poor idea to just stick to the main story all throughout, because it will leave you at a disadvantage if you ignore the varying side quests and beautiful exploration, which allow you to uncover some of the best equipment as well as enhance your skills and levels.  This in turn, has given me a massive playtime of 37 hours so far and the main story still only feels like it's a quarter of the way through!  This is a fantastic watercooler game, allowing for you and your friends to share hours of stories about your unique adventures and play style in Skyrim.  If you have the system specs and you love exploration, DO NOT MISS THIS GAME!
